sn2.18:1.2: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Sāketa in the Añjana Grove, the Deer Park.
sn2.18:1.3: Then, when the night had advanced, the young deva Kakudha,  of stunning beauty, illuminating the entire Añjana Grove, approached the Blessed One. Having approached, he paid homage to the Blessed One, stood to one side, and said to him:
sn2.18:1.8: “Then, ascetic, do you neither delight nor sorrow?”
sn2.18:2.2: I hope no delight is found in you.
sn2.18:2.3: I hope that when you sit all alone
sn2.18:3.2: Yet no delight is found in me.
sn2.18:3.3: And when I’m sitting all alone
sn2.18:4.2: How is no delight found in you?
sn2.18:4.3: How come, when you sit all alone,
sn2.18:5.1: “Delight comes to one who is miserable,
sn2.18:5.2: Misery to one filled with delight.
sn2.18:5.4: That’s how you should know me, friend.”
sn2.18:6.1: “After a long time at last I see
sn2.18:6.2: A brahmin who is fully quenched,
sn2.18:6.4: Who has crossed over attachment to the world. ”
